content: The "Walnut Canyon Study Act of 2007" authorizes a study to evaluate public uses and values, and obtain recommendations for managing and protecting resources in the study area. The "Walnut Canyon Study Act of 2007" defines key terms such as "map" and "Monument" related to the Walnut Canyon National Monument in Arizona. It also outlines various activities considered as "public use" in the study area, including livestock grazing, hunting, camping, hiking, and rock climbing. The "Walnut Canyon Study Act of 2007" defines public value in the study area, including geologic features, historic sites, urban development potential, prehistoric sites, scenery, scientific education, solitude, vegetation diversity, watershed health, wildfire hazard reduction, wildlife, and wildlife habitat. The "Walnut Canyon Study Act of 2007" identifies the study area as the "Walnut Canyon Proposed Study Area", encompassing 30,818 acres with Federal, State, private land, and the Monument. The Secretaries refer to the Secretary of the Interior and the Secretary of Agriculture acting jointly. Key aspects include wildlife, wildlife habitat, fee-free access, and recreational uses. The "Walnut Canyon Study Act of 2007" designates the study area as the "Walnut Canyon Proposed Study Area", covering 30,818 acres with Federal, State, private land, and the Monument. Key aspects include wildlife, wildlife habitat, fee-free access, and recreational uses. The Secretaries will conduct a study of the Walnut Canyon Proposed Study Area to evaluate the significance of resources, public values, opportunities for maintaining public uses, and options for managing and conserving resources by the National Park Service or Forest Service. This includes considering a boundary adjustment to the Monument and designation of the study area as a National Recreation Area. The Secretaries will consult with various government entities, designate the Forest Service as the lead agency, contract a third-party consultant for park and land use planning, and collaborate with stakeholders to develop a draft study for the Walnut Canyon Proposed Study Area. The Secretaries will review the draft study prepared by a third-party consultant for the Walnut Canyon Proposed Study Area. A report describing the study's findings and conclusions, along with a recommendation for future management, will be submitted to Congress within 18 months. This Act does not impact the management of the depicted land on the map. The Act does not affect the management of the land depicted on the map. $350,000 is authorized for carrying out the Act.
